question.text: Leucine is one of the three amino acids which are coded by 6 codons. The codons that code for leucine are <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></math>. How many minimum types of t RNA will be required for reading all codons of leucine?

solution.text: Codons for Leucine are <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></math> . Out of these, <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></math> can be read by 1 t-RNA (as they satisfy conditions for Wobble hypothesis). But UUA and UUG can only be read by another t-RNA as even though they code for same amino acid they are very different form <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></math>. Thus at least two different t-RNAs are required for reading all codons of Leucine
